igt.tag-types: M+LN+DB+EX L+DB L+DB L M G+DB M G G+DB B T+DB+LT

tier.item: (10) Japanese: The local preposition ni takes a region noun.
Hon wa teeburu no ue ni aru. `the pupil sits at a desk.'
shita x e {SIT(x) & LOC(x, AT desk)}(e)
Only the lowest argument can be incorporated into the verb. With ditransitive verbs, it is
book TOP table GEN on-region LOC be
always the recipient (construed as goal) which gets incorporated.
lit. `The book is located in the on-region of the table.' etc. mother pencil REFL-child-give-INDIC

(10) Japanese: The local preposition ni takes a region noun.
Hon wa teeburu no ue ni aru. `the pupil sits at a desk.'
shita x e {SIT(x) & LOC(x, AT desk)}
Only the lowest argument can be incorporated into the verb. With ditransitive verbs, it is
book TOP table GEN on-region LOC be
always the recipient (construed as goal) which gets incorporated.
lit. `The book is located in the on-region of the table.' etc. mother pencil REFL-child-give-INDIC
(11) I have a bike. The bike is mine. ?The bike is at me.
Ich habe ein Fahrrad. Das Fahrrad ist mir.(dialectal) ?Das Fahrrad ist bei mir.
(11) I have a bike. The bike is mine. ?The bike is at me.
Ich habe ein Fahrrad. Das Fahrrad ist mir.(dialectal) ?Das Fahrrad ist bei mir.

Ich habe ein Fahrrad. Das Fahrrad ist mir.(dialectal) ?Das Fahrrad ist bei mir.
I have a bike. The bike belongs me.
emerge, such a construction must be unmarked under other aspects. As will be shown in
Ich habe ein Fahrrad. Das Fahrrad gehört mir.

(25) a. He threw the book behind the tree.
`John liked to be a gardener.' (i.e., to behave temporarily like a gardener)

tier.item: (19) Vers with inchoative reading: P y x e {THROW(x,y) & P(y)}(e)
Das Holzwerk splitterte. u (BEC) LOC(u, BEHIND* the tree)
The woodwork splintered. throw behind the tree: y x e {THROW(x,y) & BEC LOC(y, BEH* the tree)}(e)

(20) Verbs with causative reading: Locative alternation: The predicate LOC gets incorporated into the verb itself.
Hans bündelte die Stöcke. (26) a. Anna glued all the photos at the wall.
John bundled the sticks. Anna klebte all die Photos an die Wand.
`John made the sticks to be in a bundle.' y x e {ACT(x) & BEC BUNDLE(y)}(e) glue: P y x e {GLUE(x,y) & P(y)}(e)

(21) Location verbs: these verbs have both options:
a. Hans kellerte den Wein. (27) a. Anna schickte dem Verleger die Photos.
John cellared the wine. = `John made the wine to be located in a cellar.' the.DAT publisher the.ACC photos

PO construction behaves similarly with a pronominal theme (Bresnan & Nikitina 2003)
John bridled the horse. = `John made the horse to have a bridle.'
